Explanation: How much does the focal employee engage in prohibitive voice, i.e. bringing attention to problems to improve workplace practices?
How much does the focal employee engage in promotive voice, i.e. making suggestions to improve workplace practices?
How much does the focal employee engage in moral objections, i.e.  bringing attention to others' moral worngdoing to improve workplace practices?
Do supervisors feel guilty when they think of the focal employee's voice behavior?
Do supervisors feel proud when they think of the focal employee's voice behavior?
What is supervisors' emotional response when focal employees speaks up? (E.g. angry, sad, frustrated)
How often does the employee speak up?
How much do supervisors engage in prohibitive voice themselves?
Supervisors' organization-based self-esteem
How much do supervisors engage in moral objections themselves?
How much do supervisors feel trusted by the focal employee?
How do supervisors rate the relationship between them and the focal employee, specifically regarding norms of reciprocity?
How assured are supervisors of themselves in their role?
Are supervisors overall satisfied with  focal employees' voice behavior?
How positive/negative does the focal employee frame issues when speaking up, in general?
How much do supervisors embrace communal values?
How much do supervisors embrace authoritarian values?
How much self-esteem do supervisors have?
How sure are supervisors that the focal employee would engage in unethical actions to benefit them, i.e. their supervisors?
Do supervisors feel ashamed when they think of the focal employee's voice behavior?
Do supervisors conceive of workplace issues in terms of details (low construal level) or abstract concepts (high construal level)?
